pageContext.description: A complete later Middle Bronze Age (MBA II, c.1400 - 1200 BC) early Primary Phase palstave of Group III, with ornamented faces and a trident below the stop ridge. The palstave has a well developed stop with high flanges along the sides. The septum has three moulded parallel ridges within it. The blade is wedge-shaped, with straight sides and flares to approximately 70mm in width with a slightly curved cutting edge. Each face of the blade has a vertical rib running down the middle, forming a trident where it intersects with a semi-eliptical ornament below the stop.
pageContext.notes:
This example is very similar to one from Harston, Cambridgeshire published in Evans (1881), p78, Fig 60. It probably belongs to the Taunton metalworking tradition, phase VIII / IX, which corresponds to Needhamâ€™s (1996) Period 5 1 (500-1150 CAL. BC).



Recorded from details emailed by the finder.
